column_.text_: Victory as Sweet as an Apple
The Best Friends in the World
Victory as Sweet as an Apple
The Best Friends in the World
A Vow Witnessed by the Skies
A World You Will Come to Know
So Long as We Draw Breath
If Only I Could See Them Again
The Tale of Ludwin, Lord of Grosgard
A Squad to Be Proud Of
A Little Help from the Shadows
The Holy Knight and the Bad Boy
The Man, the Myth, the Fan Art
The Woman Who Pines for Death
You Wish You Were as Cute as Moi

meets Katalina and Lyria, who are fleeing
from the Erste Empire's military.  fights
back against the pursuers and is mortally wounded.
Lyria links her life force to  in order to
save the selfless youth. The powerful connection
established between these two fated individuals
awakens the black dragon Bahamut, who proceeds to
disperse the imperial forces with a single blast of fire.

decides to set out into the skies, hoping
to draw imperial scrutiny away from Zinkenstill in
the process. 's ultimate destination is
Estalucia, the Island of the Astrals where 's
father promised he'd be waiting. At long last,
's dream of exploring the vast skies has
come true.

After departing Zinkenstill,  encounters both
new friends and difficult dilemmas. But no matter the
situation,  overcomes every obstacle and
assembles a fine skyfaring crew. The crew acquire a
Sky Map and follow it to a place they've yet to explore:
Zegagrande Skydom.

A merchant in Folca pleads for 's help. He
explains that relief supplies en route to Tempeal were
intercepted by goblins, and the crew immediately
agrees to assist. Although the loss to Id at Tempeal still
haunts  and Vyrn, they try to put the memory
of failure behind them and move on.

Vyrn confesses he feels like he's a burden on the crew.
 assures the little dragon that his stalwart
support bolsters the crew's morale and encourages Vyrn
to keep doing what he's doing. Thanks to the heartfelt
pep talk from his best buddy, Vyrn's confidence comes
roaring back.

The crew bumps into the same merchant who had
requested their help with the Tempeal supplies. When
the merchant calls Vyrn a lizard, Vyrn surprisingly
takes it in stride.  muses that Vyrn has
matured, at least just a little.

and the crew spend their days helping Id
with his Mr. Fix It duties. Id expresses worry for Lyria,
considering all that has happened. She tells him stories
about her past to assuage his concerns.

As Vyrn and Lyria continue their trip down memory lane,
Id abruptly challenges  to a duel. Perhaps Id
wishes to test the captain's resolve to protect Lyria.
Either way,  is left speechless.

The duel is intense and furious, but 
emerges victorious over Id. No further words are
needed in the aftermath; their clash of blades and
spirit spoke volumes.

Word spreads among the crew about Id and 's
duel, and the crew members share a hearty laugh over
the minor spat. Life returns to normal, but 
will never forget the weight of Id's strikes. 
vows to carry the responsibility that comes with being
both captain of the crew and recipient of Lyria's lifelink,
no matter how heavy it may be.

the selfless youth. The powerful connection established

dream of exploring the vast skies has come true.

Zegagrande Skydom.

still haunts  and Vyrn, they try to put the
memory of failure behind them and move on.

 assures the little dragon that his stalwart
support bolsters the crew's morale and encourages
Vyrn to keep doing what he's doing. Thanks to the

comes roaring back.

The crew bumps into the same merchant who had

the merchant calls Vyrn a lizard, Vyrn surprisingly takes
it in stride.  muses that Vyrn has matured, at
least just a little.

and the crew spend their days helping Id
with his Mr. Fix It duties. Id expresses worry for Lyria,
considering all that has happened. She tells him stories
about her past to assuage his concerns.

As Vyrn and Lyria continue their trip down memory lane,
Id abruptly challenges  to a duel. Perhaps Id

Either way,  is left speechless.

The duel is intense and furious, but  emerges
victorious over Id. No further words are needed in the

Word spreads among the crew about Id and 's
duel, and the crew members share a hearty laugh over
the minor spat. Life returns to normal, but 
will never forget the weight of Id's strikes. 
vows to carry the responsibility that comes with being
both captain of the crew and recipient of Lyria's lifelink,
no matter how heavy it may be.

Looking out over Zegagrande's sunny skies, Katalina
recalls how she had helped Lyria escape from the
Erste Empire, met  on Zinkenstill, and
embarked on adventures she never could've imagined.
She vows to always remain by Lyria's side.

When Katalina first met Lyria, the stoic girl could be
better described as a living doll. However, Katalina
comes to realize that Lyria doesn't know how to
express her feelings. The knight begins teaching the
girl many things and promises to someday show her
the outside world.

The experimentation on Lyria grows crueler by the day,
further fueling Katalina's distrust of the empire. Caught
between her knightly oath to Erste and the promise she
made to Lyria, she decides to take Lyria and flee from
the empire.

Tempeal is rebuilding in the aftermath of the destruction
that befell its land. Even children who can barely hold
their tools have volunteered to help rebuild their home.
Katalina offers to lend a hand, but the children insist on
doing things themselves.

When Katalina hears that a young boy named Al has
dashed into the forest alone, she gives swift pursuit.
She arrives just as a rock golem stalks toward the child.
After felling the creature, she hands the boy windcrest,
the herb he needs to cure his sister of her illness.

Katalina receives a letter from Al. Thanks to the herbs,
his little sister, Hazel, has recovered from her illness.
The letter concludes by encouraging Katalina to visit
them in Folca whenever she can.

Another letter from Al arrives. He writes that Hazel has
made a full recovery, and he's working hard on the
reconstruction effort to make up for lost time.
However, judging from the even sloppier handwriting 
and greater number of mistakes, Katalina worries that
Al is pushing himself too hard.

A third letter from Al makes Katalina's blood run cold.
Hazel has fallen ill again, and the medicinal herbs aren't
working anymore. The crew hurry back to Folca to check
on the two.

The crew returns to Folca with the wraithwing eggs
Hazel said could heal her. It turns out that Hazel had
told a white lie. She wants Al, who's been overexerting
himself, to eat the eggs and recover his health. Katalina,
having already guessed Hazel's intentions, ushers the
children to a dining hall.

Hazel and Al stuff their faces with omelets made from
the wraithwing eggs. There's enough for all of Folca.
Katalina happily watches everyone fill their stomachs
with delicious energy-restoring food.

Rackam pilots the Grandcypher out of the stormy Grim
Basin and into the blue skies of Zegagrande. Cheers
erupt from the deck, heralding excitement for new
adventures. They can't wait to make landfall.

Many years ago, young Rackam found the Grandcypher
abandoned near some cliffs. He fell in love with the
neglected airship and spent years fixing her up.
When he finally got her into the air, she crashed,
taking his dreams down with her. After that mishap,
he became disillusioned and quit flying altogether.

Tiamat, the primal beast of Port Breeze, goes berserk,
endangering everyone in Rackam's hometown. In the face
of a dire situation, Rackam overcomes his past trauma and
pilots the Grandcypher again. After helping 's
crew calm Tiamat's fury, he joins them as their helmsman.

A heated argument between several people reaches
Rackam's ears. A young engineer wants to save an
airship called the Nautilus from being scrapped despite
his friends' calls for him to let her go. Rackam is
sympathetic to the engineer but feels the ship is a lost
cause. As Rackam turns to leave, the engineer mutters
something that stops him in his tracks.

Rackam rescues a merchant's cargo from monsters at
the request of Kent the engineer. The merchant thanks
Rackam and apologizes to Kent for being so dismissive
of the engineer's goal to restore the Nautilus. Rackam
thinks to himself that it's time to put some wind back in
the Nautilus's sails.

Rackam asks Kent's mechanic friend to fix the Nautilus.
She insists that without rare parts, the ship will never
fly again, regardless of her wishes. When Rackam finally
gets a word in edgewise, he reveals he's already collected
those parts and hands them to the astonished mechanic.

Repairs to the Nautilus are proceeding smoothly. The
next time Kent sees Rackam, he excitedly relays how
his mechanic friend got a second wind after receiving
rare parts from a generous skyfarer. Rackam acts
clueless, but deep down, he wishes for Kent's dream
to come true.

The Nautilus is ready for a test flight, but Kent's
helmsman friend looks conflicted. Rackam realizes
the helmsman fears taking to the skies. Having dealt
with his own issues about flying, Rackam sympathizes
with the man.

Rackam takes the timid helmsman on a flight aboard
the Grandcypher, hoping the experience will allay the
man's fears. Rackam's gamble works. With a renewed
sense of determination, the transformed helmsman
promises to fly the Nautilus for himself and his friends.

Nearly the entire town attends the Nautilus's maiden
voyage. With a roaring of engines and whirring of
propellers, the ship climbs into the skies, carrying the
promises and dreams of Kent and his friends.

Valtz Duchy is an island of intense heat that Io calls
home. When her master goes missing, she teams up
with the crew to find him. The search isn't easy, but
they eventually locate and rescue him from his madness.
She learns that the Erste Empire played a part in his
disappearance and decides to join the crew to get
revenge on the imperials.

Io was orphaned three years ago when her parents
passed away from an epidemic. It was Tzaka the
Great, the archduke of Valtz Duchy, who took her
in and taught her that magic exists to make people
happy. From that day forth, she trains as a mage
under his tutelage.

During Io's travels with the crew, she mysteriously loses
her ability to use magic. They return to Valtz Duchy to
see if they can find an answer. Coincidently, the same
epidemic that claimed Io's parents is spreading in Valtz
again. It appears to be caused by an evil spirit. While
preparing to fight the spirit, Io obtains her mother's staff,
which restores her magic. With her late mother's help, Io
defeats the spirit.

The calm in Folca is broken by a boy named Lev. He
screams that he hates all the adults in the village before
running off into the forest. One man starts to chase after
him but is held back by other townsfolk. Io learns that the
man is Lev's father, a doctor who must prioritize his
patients before his son. Picturing the boy crying alone is
too much for Io to bear—she and the crew head into the
forest to search for him.

The crew saves Lev from monsters. A member of the
Folcan Defense Corps arrives to escort the boy home.
Lev rebuffs the corps member's hand, yelling it's the
adults' fault, and flees deeper into the forest. Io
frantically chases after him.

Io finally tracks down Lev after a long search. She
performs a magic trick her master had taught her, which
comforts the boy, especially when he gets a piece of
candy at the end. The treat lifts his spirits for a second,
but he immediately becomes depressed again.

Lev eventually trusts Io enough to explain the reason
for his outbursts. His parents were doctors in Tempeal,
and they had lost their home in the Furycane disaster.
Ever since coming to Folca, his parents saw patients
without rest, causing his mother to collapse from
exhaustion. Io senses that Lev is simply sick with worry
for his parents' well-being.

Lev continues to confide in Io, confessing that he feels
like the townspeople are taking advantage of his
parents' kindness and duty as doctors. He fears his
distrust means he can never become a great doctor
like his parents. Io persuades him to see the situation
differently and suggests they go back to Folca.

On the way back to Folca, Io and Lev hear the boy's
parents calling for him through the trees. Suddenly,
a giant goblin ambushes his parents, and the
townspeople quickly jump in to protect them. This
buys Io time to fend off the goblin. After seeing how
the townspeople came to his family's rescue, Lev
apologizes for his behavior.

Lev speaks frankly with his parents about what's
bothering him. His mom and dad promise they'll soon
have more time to spend together after a group of
doctors from Seedhollow move to Folca. Finally, the
boy is able to smile again.

Eugen traveled far and wide as an accomplished
skyfarer before retiring to his homeland of the
Auguste Isles. There he joined other mercenaries
to defend Auguste against the Erste Empire's incursion.
After teaming up with 's crew to fight the
imperials, he decides to face his past—one he has
been neglecting for a long time.

When Eugen's wife was diagnosed with an incurable
disease, Eugen refused to accept her fate. He set out
into the skies, leaving his wife and daughter behind in
order to hunt for a cure. However, Eugen was too late;
his wife passed while he was away. When he rushed
home, his daughter had disappeared, leaving only a
broken man. That was over a decade ago.

During his travels with , Eugen encounters
his estranged and now-adult daughter. She still hates
him for being absent when her mother died. When
Eugen makes a pact with primal beast Leviathan, he
witnesses a vision of his late wife, who gives him the
courage and determination to keep moving forward.

One day while wandering around Folca, Eugen
encounters a young man racked with guilt. His name
is Kharzeda, and he lost his childhood friend in the
storm that hit Tempeal before he could tell her his
true feelings.

Kharzeda's deceased friend loved flowers, and her
dream was to make them bloom in Tempeal's barren
soil. Kharzeda asks Eugen to search the mines for her
gardening tools. The mines have been overrun by
goblins, but it's nothing the crew can't handle. They
find the precious tools and return them to Kharzeda.

Eugen accompanies Kharzeda to the cemetery. Kharzeda
breaks down upon seeing his friend's grave, his tears
mixing with the torrential rain. Eugen quietly lets the man
pour out his regrets and frustrations, knowing how
essential it is to the healing process.

Kharzeda asks Eugen how he's supposed to live with
his regrets. Eugen decides to tell Kharzeda about losing
his wife. The old skyfarer suggests Kharzeda might gain
closure by finding out what his friend was trying to
achieve.

Kharzeda's friend's dream was to fill Tempeal with
flowers. He knows she had a secret garden where she
could test out gardening methods, but he has no idea
where it could be. Eugen and Kharzeda head for the
forest on Folca's edge to search for clues.

Eugen and Kharzeda locate the secret garden, but
monsters have trampled the flower beds. Kharzeda once
again loses hope. Amid the debris of broken tools and
decaying plants, Eugen finds a notebook filled with notes,
botanical records, and directions to another garden.

Eugen and Kharzeda reach the other secret garden.
Sunlight filters through the forest canopy, shining down
on purple flowers. Kharzeda finally understands what
his friend had been trying to tell him.

As Rosetta gazes at the sunny skies of Zegagrande, the
forgotten skydom, she thinks back to how she arrived at
this point. Her adventures with 's crew feel like
a blip in her long existence, but that doesn't make the
trip any less meaningful.

Once upon a time, a primal beast put down roots in
the Lumacie Archipelago after she was severely
wounded in the War. Centuries would pass, and she'd
lose a battle to a young man who came to her island.
Instead of dealing the finishing blow, the young man
invited the primal to join his crew. He gave her the
name Rosetta.

Toward the end of the man's journey, Rosetta returned
to the forests of Lumacie. Many years would pass
before another young traveler crossed her path. This
youth was , the child of the man with whom
she once adventured.

A mysterious young girl appearing in the dead of night
has been spotted searching for something in Seedhollow
Castle. The crew agrees to investigate the strange
sightings.

The crew encounter Ominous Forms, creatures found
in the Pillar of Vayoi, during their investigation of the
castle. After defeating the shadowy monsters, Rosetta
picks up a strange crystal fragment that emits a faint
glow similar to that of hallowed ground. It also seems
to give off Excavallion's aura. Lyria detects the presence
of yet another primal coming from inside the castle.

Despite their best efforts, the crew's investigation
finds no sign of the mystery girl. It's Zathba who
breaks the case open; he reports that the girl wears
a crown of flowers. Thanks to this clue, Rosetta
believes the girl is actually a primal beast called
Konohanasakuya.

Rosetta explains that 's father knew how
to release primals from Astral power. Some primals
see this as liberation, while others misinterpret
his actions as extermination. Rosetta suspects
Konohanasakuya believes in the latter.

Even though the crew has uncovered the girl's true
identity, they're still far from closing the books on this
mystery. Yet again, the Family Zathba comes through
with a clue. Dagger hands Rosetta a book that was
found near the Konohanasakuya sightings.

Rosetta deciphers the book's text, which suggests
a clue may lie on Dahli Island. The crew finds a
crystal similar to the one they found in the castle
and bring it back to Seedhollow. They install the
new crystal beneath the castle, and it emits a green
light that should prevent Ominous Forms and their
ilk from returning, much to the crew's relief.

Seedhollow returns to normal. When the clients that
requested the investigation are informed that the girl
is actually a primeval god, they're relieved. However,
one loose end still remains: Lyria is sad Rosetta and
Konohanasakuya couldn't patch things up.

Ferry lived on a mist-shrouded island with her parents
and sister. Her sister contracted an incurable disease
and left the island to find treatment. Some time after,
a plague swept the island, claiming the lives of Ferry's
parents and many islanders. Ferry herself grew ill.
Desperate, she prayed to the skies, but she was
answered by the primal beast of death, Celeste, who
turned the remaining villagers into living corpses. Ferry,
however, curiously became a ghost.

Ferry lost her family, but she found companionship
in her ghostly pets, Beppo, Geegee, Fugee, and
Nicola. When 's crew later arrive on the
mist-shrouded island, they discover they're trapped
there unless they defeat Celeste and clear the mist.
But in doing so, Ferry and all the zombie villagers
will cease to exist.

Ferry and the crew overcome various obstacles before
squaring off against and defeating Celeste. As expected,
the villagers are released from their undead state and
pass on, but strangely, Ferry and her pets remain.
 invites her to join the crew, and she accepts.
Her journey to reunite with her long-lost little sister has
just begun.

Ferry encounters a woman sewing a blanket in
Seedhollow's central plaza. The woman, Melphira,
says the blanket is a gift for her beloved. Ferry takes
a seat beside Melphira to watch her work. Melphira,
who was all smiles, sighs out of the blue.

Melphira had dismissed Ferry's claims of being a
skyfarer, pointing to the fact that Ferry looks too
young. However, when Ferry presents Melphira with
magic thread that can only be found in Phondam,
Melphira apologizes for her initial skepticism and
thanks Ferry profusely.

Melphira's lover is a geologist who is currently
surveying Dahli Island, where the nights get bitterly
cold, hence the reason she's knitting him a blanket.
She happily says he'll return to Seedhollow next month.
Although Ferry is happy for Melphira, something
doesn't sit right with her.

A month later, Ferry visits a visibly troubled Melphira.
Her partner didn't come back as promised. Ferry
tries to cheer her up by suggesting he'll definitely
come back next month, but Melphira isn't so sure.

Yet another month passes by and Melphira's lover
still hasn't returned. Trying to break the oppressive
mood, Ferry asks how Melphira and her partner met.
Recounting the romantic story for the crew raises
her spirits a little. To Ferry's dismay, Melphira decides
she'll go to Dahli herself to find out what's going on.

Ferry and the crew offer to go to Dahli in Melphira's
stead. After a brief investigation, they find a cemetery
featuring a small memorial for the victims of the Dahli
disaster that occurred fifteen years ago. Among the
list of victims name's is the name of Melphira's lover.
Ferry leaves the blanket at the memorial.

The crew returns to Seedhollow. Ferry can't bear
to tell Melphira the truth, so she lies to her that her
lover is doing well. Melphira, of course, is no fool. She
realized long ago that the regret of not being able to
give him the blanket kept her from passing on. She
thanks Ferry for her kindness and fades from the world.

King Carl of Feendrache urges Lancelot to expand his
horizons. And so, the knight joins 's crew
on their journey.

As a child, Lancelot dreamed of becoming a knight
for the purpose of creating a kingdom free of monster
attacks. At the time, the aristocracy reigned supreme,
meaning commoners like Lancelot were barred from
knighthood. Despite this, Lancelot studied and trained
hard enough to become one. Not content to stop there,
he eventually becomes captain of the White Dragons.

A crisis looms over Feendrache. Lancelot mistakenly
judges his former mentor Siegfried to be the traitor
behind a conspiracy. With Vane and the crew's help,
they uncover the true mastermind and save the
kingdom. Afterward, the king commands Lancelot to
join 's crew and gain valuable experience
traveling the skies.

A butler named Hans has a job for Lancelot. His
master, Ludwin, Lord of Grosgard, had heard of
Lancelot's deeds and personally requests his services
as a bodyguard. Although Lancelot has some doubts,
he thinks working for the lord may prove a useful
learning experience and accepts the job.

Lancelot meets Ludwin and Hans on Mt. Neigelith.
They are looking for old documents chronicling the
whereabouts of a mythical sword passed down from
generation to generation. When they eventually find
the documents, they discover the text is written in
code. Hans offers to give Ludwin a hint, but the lord
firmly declares he must decipher the text on his own.

Before long, Hans appears before Lancelot with
another request. Ludwin is having no luck deciphering
the code. Hans already knows the answer, having
solved it with the previous lord, but he reasons that
Ludwin should figure it out for himself. However, that
doesn't mean Lancelot can't help Ludwin.

Lancelot examines the code but is also unable to crack
it. He suggests enlisting outside help. He gets in touch
with Zathba who in turn gets in touch with another
expert. Through this sequence of events, the code can
be broken at long last.

Ludwin tells Lancelot that he has figured out where
the sword is: the monster-ridden Skywyrm Valley. In
other words, Ludwin hopes Lancelot will escort him
through the valley. The knight gladly accepts this duty,
believing he can help shape Ludwin's development as
a leader.

Ludwin's entourage overcomes many trials to reach
the precious sword. With great anticipation, Ludwin
picks up his reward only to find that it's all hilt and no
blade. The man is crestfallen, but Lancelot urges him
to consider the true meaning behind the sword.

Ludwin visits Lancelot a few days later, claiming that
he has come to understand the message behind the
sword passed down by his ancestors: "One person
does not make a country. I am the hilt, which guides
the sword." Ludwin gives Lancelot his heartfelt thanks.

Vane has always dreamed of being a hero. Starting
from an early age, he did everything in his power to
make that dream come true. As the years went on, his
best friend and hero, Lancelot, left their hometown
and became a knight. From that moment on, Vane
decided to follow in Lancelot's footsteps.

Vane first meets 's crew as he's hurrying
back to Feendrache's capital. He has heard that
True Dragon Fafnir has been revived, and Lancelot
is prepping to lead an army against it. Vane confesses
to  he fears he's not strong enough to
support his best friend Lancelot on the battlefield.
 invites Vane to join the crew so that he
can become stronger.

Thanks to his many accomplishments, Vane is
promoted to vice-captain of the White Dragons,
though not all of the knights are convinced he has
earned his rank. The criticisms send Vane spiraling.
The crew enlists the help of Siegfried, Percival, and
of course, Lancelot to lift Vane out of his funk. With
the support of his friends, Vane renews his goal to
become a hero.

Vane is enjoying a walk in Folca when a group of kids
calling themselves the Bluesky Knights demand that
he identify himself. Not wanting to embarrass the
children for accosting a fellow knight, Vane introduces
himself as a chef, which immediately wins them over.

The Bluesky Knights plus Vane scour the forest for a
good place to establish their hideout. Vane discovers
the perfect spot, and the kids immediately hoist their
knightly flag. Hanging out with the kids reminds him
so much of his own childhood that he decides to hang
out with them for a little longer.

Whenever Vane happens to be in Folca, he pays the
Bluesky Knights a visit. The children brim with curiosity
and seem to want to learn everything about anything.
Vane gladly obliges, but the most important lesson he
wants them to remember is to know when to ask for help.

One day, Vane notices a sad-looking boy sitting
against a wall by himself. Skip says the boy came
from Tempeal, dismissing the stranger as a crybaby
to be ignored. Vane disagrees—shouldn't knights reach
out to those in need? Skip instantly changes his tune.
He rushes over to the new kid and immediately inducts
him as a member of the Bluesky Knights.

The Bluesky Knights nickname their newest member
Newbs. It doesn't take long for Newbs to come out
of his shell. Vane and the children enjoy hanging out
at their forest hideout and pigging out on Vane's cooking.

Vane's latest trip to Folca is different. Newbs had
gotten lost in the forest, prompting the Bluesky
Knights to go search for him without telling any adults,
which results in everyone but Ace getting lost as well.
Vane hurries into the forest, finds the kids, and rescues
them from a monster attack just in time. Vane's true
identity as a knight is revealed, and to his surprise, the
kids don't mind they were kept in the dark.

When Vane questions the kids why they rushed into
the forest after Newbs without telling anyone, they
reply it was their knightly duty to help anyone in need.
Vane winces. It was the right idea, applied at the wrong
time. Rather than compliment the kids, he gives them
a stern lecture. Vane and the children take a knight's
oath to know when to ask for help.

Percival is on a mission to create a model country.
He joined 's crew to realize his aspiration,
but everywhere he went, he was only treated to
scenes of violence. He wonders if the new skydom
will present him with at least one country of peace.

When Percival was a child, his homeland of Wales
was impacted by a war in a neighboring country. He
lost his mother not to the war itself, but to the very
people she saved. This tragedy changed his life
profoundly, and he strove to create a nation in which
everyone can live in peace.

It's customary for the House of Wales to enlist their
sons in the military of allied nations. Percival joined
Feendrache's Black Dragons and became a
vice-captain. However, Feendrache would suffer a
crisis in which Percival's eldest brother, Aglovale, is
revealed to be the mastermind. With the help of
's crew, they stop his brother's scheme.
This event further bolsters Percival's resolve to
create the ideal country.

Percival inspects the Folcan Defense Corps for
potential vassal candidates and finds nothing but
incompetence and ineptitude. He feels compelled to
determine the source of the Corps's weaknesses.

Percival stops an Aviaeth follower from harming a
resident of Folca, earning the ire of other Aviaeth
adherents. They challenge Percival to a fight on the
outskirts of town. The troublemakers are quickly
defeated and flee, making way for a new set of
troublemakers: the Folcan Defense Corps. The Corps
accuses Percival of stirring up trouble and takes him
into custody. The Lord of Flames simply laughs and
goes along willingly.

Brought to the Defense Corps's guardhouse, Percival
turns the table on the interrogators. Arguing with
sound logic, Percival wins his acquittal and demands
to know how the Corps fell into such disarray. Upon
learning the reason, Percival feels compelled to whip
the Corps into shape.

The next morning, Percival returns to the guardhouse
with a laundry list of the Corps members' shortcomings.
Emotions boil over and punches are thrown, though
none connect with Percival. Finally, the Corps captain
dares Percival to take his job, which Percival does
without batting an eye. The Lord of Flames puts his new
regimen in place.

Percival deems that the Corps members have made
sufficient progress with their training and schedules
a patrol through Folca. The residents give them a
negative reception as expected. Undeterred, Percival
makes a public apology for the Corps's past mistakes
and promises to do better. This show of humility
galvanizes the Corps members to train even harder.

Remnants of Avia have taken hostages in Tempeal.
Percival and the crew safely rescue the hostages
and arrest the hostage takers. The scoundrels gloat
about sending their main force to capture Folca, but
Percival knew that was their plan all along. When they
return to Folca, the Defense Corps and their Avia
prisoners are waiting for them at the gate.

The time has come for Percival to return to his original
mission of building the ideal country. Percival hands
back the title of captain. It's a bittersweet goodbye,
but he expresses his hope that the Corps will help him
improve his country when the time comes. They all
respond with a sincere salute.

Siegfried was the captain of Feendrache's Black Dragons
until a conspiracy forced him into exile. With the aid of
 and Lancelot, he was able to rid his homeland
of danger and clear his name. He currently travels with
the crew, watching over 's journey to the
promised land.

In his youth, Siegfried was wild and arrogant, and got
along with no one. Then one day, he rescued the
wounded King Josef, who knighted him for his deed.
It changed his life forever. However, Siegfried would
never have another chance to thank the king. To this
very day, Siegfried wields his sword in service of his
homeland and the late King Josef.

Siegfried's fall from grace begins when he's framed
for regicide. Despite being labeled a fugitive, his fire
to settle the conspiracy continues to burn. 's
crew plays a large role in shedding light on the truth.
After saving his homeland from certain ruin, he joins
the crew.

Always thinking about how to help Feendrache,
Siegfried begins his analysis of Seedhollow's military
to determine whether it's a future ally or threat.

Vyrn tags along with Siegfried on his self-selected
intelligence gathering mission. They tail a squad of
Seedhollow soldiers and observe how they handle
monsters. The soldiers are not lacking in morale but
ability. Siegfried is unable to idly watch and jumps in
to defeat the monsters. Vyrn grows indignant when
the soldiers complain of Siegfried's meddling, but
Siegfried apologizes and takes his leave.

Vyrn asks Siegfried why he apologized even though
the soldiers were rude to him. Siegfried responds
that the soldiers fought bravely against the threat.
Even though they suffered defeat, it's all part of the
learning process, which, in the end, should benefit
both their combat ability and pride.

Siegfried digs into Seedhollow's history. The country
has been at peace for such a long period of time that
its soldiers rarely have the opportunity to acquire
combat experience. Siegfried determines that
Seedhollow poses little threat to Feendrache—in fact,
he may be able to improve the green troops.

Siegfried and Vyrn resume surveilling the Seedhollow
soldiers, who operate more along the lines of a militia
than an army. When the soldiers set off to exterminate
goblins, Vyrn is worried, but Siegfried thinks this will be
a good learning experience for them.

Vyrn and Siegfried thin out the goblin ranks before the
Seedhollow soldiers arrive. With the threat greatly
lessened, the soldiers gain valuable experience and
confidence without exposing themselves to great danger.

The captain of Seedhollow's forces pays a surprise
visit to the Grandcypher to speak with Siegfried.
The captain thanks Siegfried for his help as well as
apologizing for his previous rudeness. He recognized
that his soldiers had been saved while still gaining
experience. Hearing this assessment, Siegfried
expects great things from Seedhollow's military.

As a child, Charlotta's life was saved by the Lumiel
Order of Holy Knights. She immediately idolized the
courageous knights, and she poured her blood, sweat,
and tears into sword training. Thanks to her efforts,
Charlotta was accepted as a knight, and she quickly
rose up the ranks to become captain.

Captain Charlotta of the Lumiel Order of Holy Knights
has a dilemma: how can she preserve the order's
prestige given her extremely short stature? Upon
hearing rumor of a miracle height tonic, she discreetly
slips away from her post to obtain some for herself.

On her way to the village that sells the height tonic,
Charlotta meets 's crew. They help her
get the tonic, which turns out to be ineffectual.
Charlotta's dreams are dashed, but when she learns
 is heading for Estalucia, she is presented
with a new hope. Thus the captain of the holy knights
joins 's crew.

Soupstock complains to Charlotta that an aristocratic
client refuses to pay for information that was delivered
in full, damaging Soupstock's pride and credibility.
Suddenly, the client's servant arrives with a note for
Soupstock saying the client will pay the money.
Charlotta senses treachery and accompanies Soupstock
to the drop-off spot.

The client springs his trap on Charlotta and Soupstock,
ambushing them with tayu'itar, war machines created
by Avia. The crew make short work of the assailants,
and the nobleman has no choice but to pay up.
Soupstock thanks Charlotta, to which the Harvin knight
proudly proclaims she was merely upholding the creed
of the holy knights.

Despite resolving the issue of unpaid debt, Soupstock's
confidence in himself has been severely shaken.
Charlotta's words of encouragement don't seem to have
much of an effect on his mood.

Soupstock asks Charlotta to meet him at a tavern. He
reveals that the unscrupulous nobleman has been
spreading rumors around Seedhollow in an attempt to
tank the Family Zathba's reputation. Soupstock intends
to settle the score with the nobleman and asks Charlotta
to be his bodyguard in case of another attack like last
time.

Charlotta and Soupstock work steadily to dispel the
falsehoods the nobleman had spread. As they gather
more information, the nobleman's true machination
comes to light: he aims to run the Family Zathba out
of town.

Charlotta dispatches the nobleman's Aviaeth thugs,
then Soupstock and the nobleman engage in a war of
words. The nobleman doesn't realize he's being
broadcast for all the townspeople to hear and
unwittingly exposes his evil masterplan. When the
cries of outraged townsfolk reach his ears, he knows
he's finished.

Soupstock admires Charlotta's swordplay, and he sadly
laments how weak he is. His loyal underlings quickly
rush to raise his spirits, speaking highly of their boss.
When even Zathba, the big man himself, comes over
to slap a hand on Soupstock's shoulder and praise him,
the mohawked man bursts into grateful tears.

There once was a world-renowned swordsman who
trained scores of disciples. On one fateful day, his top
student betrayed his principles of swordsmanship and
went rogue. He tracked her down and wounded her in
a duel but couldn't bring himself to deliver the final
blow. He discarded his title and prestige—his very
past—and vanished from society.

The former master swordsman lives as a recluse in
the mountains, fishing the days away. When word
reaches him that his fallen disciple is causing trouble
again, he joins 's crew for the chance to
stop her.

The swordmaster's mercy has inadvertently resulted
in more innocent deaths at the hands of the disciple
he couldn't kill. This time he is hell-bent on finishing
what he started and dons his burial garb. However,
his resolve crumbles again at the last moment.
Another young disciple he once trained is the one to
end the fated feud.

Yodarha looks forward to a casual day of fishing in
unfamiliar waters of the new skydom. Unfortunately,
it seems his gear isn't up to par. Paying a visit to
Sierokarte to upgrade his tackle, the merchant mentions
a rumor about an expert angler called the Fishergod.

An elderly gent stands on a ridge overlooking a sea of
lava, his line cast into the fiery waves. When Vyrn
expresses doubt that he'll catch anything besides rocks,
the man calmly answers with cryptic fishing adages.
This is proof enough for Yodarha that the man is the
Fishergod.

Yodarha and the Fishergod are evenly-matched, reeling
in fish after fish from the lava flow. A casual comment
from Vyrn—who's the better fisherman?—ignites the
spirit of competition in the two masters. The Fishergod
mentions that elusive legendary fish appear periodically
in Zegagrande. Whoever catches one first is the winner.

Before Yodarha can catch a legendary fish, he needs
to learn more about it. He speaks with as many
knowledgeable people as he can, but his search yields
little results. Just when it looks like he's about to run
out of time, he gets a bite.

Yodarha proudly displays his legendary catch to the
Fishergod. The astonished fisherman has never seen
such a species before, yet he too presents a different
legendary fish of his own. The result of the duel is
essentially a draw, an outcome that doesn't sit well
with either angler.

Today is the day the people determine which fisherman
has created the most happiness with their catch. The
Fishergod presents the biggest fish in Zegagrande, while
Yodarha shows off a wagon-load of common shalmon.
All but one vote for the Fishergod. Yodarha's single vote
comes from a little boy. When the Fishergod hears the
reason behind the boy's vote, he realizes he has lost.

The Fishergod explains his reason for conceding. Common
fish fuel people in their daily lives, thus promoting good
health, which is the source of everyday happiness. Both
anglers express mutual satisfaction over their intense
competition, and they promise this won't be the last of
their matches.

Narmaya comes from a long line of renowned warriors.
As a child, she admired another strong warrior named
Zanba who would later become Eahta of the Eternals.
Narmaya trained hard and surpassed all other students
at her dojo. Unfortunately for her, Zanba left the dojo
without ever uttering her name.

's crew found Narmaya while she was
meditating in a forest. They had sought her out in the
hopes that she'd teach them martial arts. Narmaya
sees the same fire of Zanba in 's eyes and
decides to join the crew.

The fated reunion between Narmaya and Zanba
culminates in a clash of blades. She leaves nothing
on the table in their duel, venting her emotions after
all these years. The battle concludes with Zanba
acknowledging her by name. With her hang-ups
resolved, Narmaya reiterates her desire to journey
with the crew.

Narmaya has never felt as weak and helpless as the
time she lost to Id, resulting in Lyria's abduction.
Blaming the loss on inadequate training, she vows to
train herself and prevent future harm from coming to
the crew by preemptively snapping up any dangerous
requests.

Narmaya slays the brutal goblin in the blink of an eye,
thus completing her request, and returns to Sierokarte
for more jobs. The merchant is astonished by her speed
and offers her another dangerous mission, which
Narmaya accepts without hesitation.

Narmaya completes one risky request after another.
As a result, the other crew members are left with
relatively safe and easy missions. Meanwhile, the
butterfly warrior continues her one-woman tour of
destruction for a singular purpose: to protect her
cherished crew.

On her days off, Narmaya meditates on the deck of
the Grandcypher. Worried crew members come to
check on her haggard condition but seeing their kind
faces only reinforces Narmaya's mindset that she has
to do everything herself. She continues to meditate,
unaware that she's on the wrong track.

The day finally comes when the crew accepts a
dangerous request before Narmaya can get her hands
on it. Realizing the futility of trying to monopolize job
requests, she believes her only recourse is to exterminate
every last monster in the skies before they can hurt her
loved ones.

Narmaya seeks out the largest monster nest in the
skydom and cuts through countless monsters on her
way to the innermost chamber. In the face of the
strongest monster, her strength finally fails. Luckily,
she's saved by the crew at the last second. Feeling
the warmth of 's hand, she realizes that
she hurts others by putting herself in danger.

A relaxed Narmaya is back to her old ways of doting on
. She has cleared her heart of turmoil and
focuses on taking care of the crew members.

Ghandagoza, master of the Eternal Rage Style, feels
his fists tremble with anticipation. They're telling him
something terrible will befall a sky he's never seen
before. It doesn't matter what obstacles appear in his
path; he'll crush them all with his fists. With a roar of
defiance, he challenges an unknown, powerful enemy.

Ghandagoza dreams of demolishing the Almighty with
a single punch. He honed his body and techniques into
a force to be reckoned with, but even he can't stop the
sands of time. He hopes to find a successor in
 and pass on his style after 
reaches Estalucia.

Eugen and Rackam shoot the breeze about various
urban legends attributed to Ghandagoza. They find
the stories hard to believe, yet recall an incident in
which they witnessed the Draph pulverize a meteor
into dust with his bare hands. Perhaps there is some
truth to the legends after all.

According to Sierokarte, a lone martial artist defeated
a few hundred troops on Mt. Neigelith, all while quelling
a raging blizzard. And not just any troops but remnants
of Avia's forces that specialize in guerrilla warfare.

The small detachment of Aviaeth forces deploys a
Tayu'itar against the mystery brawler to no avail and
are forced to retreat. Despite the terrifying battle
that unfolded, there isn't a single death. One Aviaeth
soldier interprets this mercy as if the brawler had
pulled his punches—he shudders at the thought that
things could've been more devastating for them.

Ghandagoza looks back fondly on his training on
Mt. Neigelith where he battled tough monsters, Aviaeth
soldiers, and the elements. With those foes bested, he
now battles boredom. That is until Lyria stops by with a
letter from a new challenger: Gallanza of the Silver Wolf
Corps.

Gallanza explains in his letter that his subordinates had
told him how they'd been trounced by a monstrously
powerful martial artist. Sensing he's found a worthy
opponent, Gallanza invites Ghandagoza to a deathmatch.
Their ring will be the Tredame Sanctum atop Mt. Neigelith.

It's time for Ghandagoza to face a dream opponent.
His heart races with excitement. He and his personal
cheer squad of Lyria, Vyrn, and  head for
Mt. Neigelith to meet his potential equal.

A bout of mass destruction ensues, one that Vyrn likens
to warring primals. Ghandagoza emerges victorious over
Gallanza, registering yet another feat to his already long
list of legendary accomplishments.

Tales of Ghandagoza's exploits seem to grow more
outlandish with each retelling. Not only did he take
down Gallanza one-on-one, but the shockwave from
his fists bore through a mountain, carved out a valley,
and even flipped the island upside down. An awestruck
Rackam muses that punching a god into oblivion is
probably within his grasp.

Zeta joined an organization called the Society, not
because she sympathized with their goals, but because
they reward their members via meritocracy. She spends
her days slaying primal beasts, clashing with a rival
organization called the Foe, and spoiling herself with
her hard-earned cash.

Zeta was once a member of a band of knights. Never
one for formality, an incident one day led her to leave
her post. Working for the Society later, she met
 and became familiar with the crew. Freely
soaring the skies, Zeta honed her skills, always finding
a fight to be in.

By her superior Ilsa's orders, Zeta begins working
alongside Vaseraga, but the man's wild and
uncooperative nature proves a headache. Struggling
to fulfill their duties, she one day learns of Vaseraga's
sad past. It is then she realizes why she was chosen
to be the reckless Vaseraga's partner.

While stopping in Seedhollow after a job, Zeta receives
a marriage proposal from an unfamiliar boy far younger
than herself. She lets it pass as a childish joke, but the
boy doggedly—and earnestly—refuses to give up.

After a job in Phondam, Zeta brings back a beautiful
stone she picked up as a souvenir for Vahn. He's
delighted, as expected—and him being a child, she
refuses to entertain the affection he shows her.

Zeta sees Vahn again back in Seedhollow and is invited
on a picnic. Vaseraga, happening to be present, offers
them the sandwiches he was making. The two make
their way over to a park just outside of town and have
a friendly chat.

Vahn gifts Zeta a wrapped box from a fancy patisserie.
The decidedly un-childlike present proves the
earnestness of Vahn's feelings, so Zeta decides to
acknowledge them properly—and insists that he not
overextend himself from now on.

Vahn suddenly states he'll start working harder to
marry Zeta, his feelings seemingly renewed by the
events of the other day. Advised to think for himself
how to become someone who balances his partner,
he brags about his proficiency with a sword. Zeta
can't help but find it precious how Vahn's emotions
are like an open book.

When Vahn interferes in a battle against Maglielle,
Zeta gives him a scolding. Her harsh words leave
him brooding, a sight that makes her heart
ache—though Vaseraga then changes the mood.
Meanwhile, she promises Maglielle the tastiest
sweets in all the skydoms to make up for it.

After some time, Vahn shows up to tell Zeta, with a
serious expression, that he wants to call off his
proposal. Zeta is confused by how the conversation
sounds almost as if she were being dumped, but
looks back fondly on her days with Vahn, even the
troublesome parts.

Vaseraga remade his own body after losing the crew
he commanded. As part of the Society, he devotes
his days to hunting primal beasts and enemy
organizations as a contractor with the seal weapon
Grynoth. Whenever he encounters something he can't
protect, he ponders his life's meaning.

Vaseraga joined the Society desiring a healthy reason
to live: protecting others. His superior introduces him
to Zeta, who at first he finds disagreeable for speaking
her mind bluntly. But finding she snaps at him all the
more when he's distant, he ponders how best to handle
this.

Vaseraga joins 's crew. Knowing the harsh
destiny that may await them, he vows to be their
shield. But in a fight with the Moondwellers, he runs
amok and bares fangs at an ally. Tormented by his
intolerable mistake, he looks to sacrifice himself, but
his partner Zeta stops him.

While headed alone to the woods near Folca to give
Grynoth a tune-up, Vaseraga spots a girl with a strange
aura in a vegetable garden. Startled by his bizarre
appearance, the girl promptly hides in her house. Yet
the black haze surrounding that girl weighs on his mind.

Vaseraga escorts the girl home, clearing up her
misunderstanding of him as the Grim Reaper. Yet
the garden she was tending to has been devastated
since he saw it last, as if swallowed up by decay. In
consideration for the haggard girl, he promises to
come back later—but senses someone's gaze.

Troubled by the decayed garden and the girl's
condition, Vaseraga returns to the woods. He learns
that the girl, Irene, tends to the garden in the woods
alone. When asked about her bandaged wrist, she
claims it's just a small injury. And it seems she is
unaware of the black haze he saw hanging about her.

Vaseraga brings Vyrn and Lyria to the garden to cheer
up Irene. Encouraged to open up, Irene tells them her
story. Never good with people, she liked caring for
plants, and recently began hearing their voices. But
this was a short-lived joy, as they suddenly withered
for some reason, leaving Irene in despair.

After a job, Vaseraga visits Irene's garden to find
every flower and plant wilted. Running inside the
house, he finds a letter on the floor: a message to
Irene from Avia missionaries aiming to convert her.
Troubled by the mention of magic items, and with
no time to think, he pursues the remnant missionaries.

Vaseraga saves Irene from the Avia battleship, and
seeing the magic item on her arm, recalls the incident
with Lyria—forcibly destroying it could mean the loss
of her life as well. But with no time to search for other
options, driven by Irene's words, Vaseraga swings down
Grynoth with purpose.

Some time later, Vaseraga finds Irene's garden revived,
filled with vivid flowers and bountiful vegetables. He
apologizes for her loss of the power to hear plants,
but she apologizes back, blaming herself for going
along with Avia. After hearing her speak, he returns to
the ship with scarcely another word.

A girl stares into a mirror, and the cutest girl in the
whole wide world, Cagliostro, stares back at her.
The alchemist prepares for another day of displaying
her beauty and brilliance for the world.

Two thousand years ago, Cagliostro was lying at
death's door. In desperation, she founded alchemy
and used it to transfer her soul into various vessels.
Over years of repeating this process, other alchemists
came to fear her power and sealed her away.

's crew unknowingly frees Cagliostro from
her imprisonment. She considers eliminating these
witnesses to her release, but her curiosity in Lyria's
existence gets the better of her. She offers to join the
crew in exchange for access to Lyria as a research
subject. It's an offer  can't refuse.

While perusing a shop for experimental resources, a
man carries a vial of strong toxin that catches
Cagliostro's eye. The man introduces himself as Himmel
and says the toxin is a pigment his little sister, Schnee,
uses in her paintings. Something about the way Himmel
mentions his sister sticks out to Cagliostro. She half
forces him to bring her to see Schnee's paintings.

The crew gathers ingredients on Mt. Neigelith for
Cagliostro to formulate a medicine that relieves
Schnee's symptoms. However, the effect is only
temporary; Schnee's auto-immune disease is incurable
by conventional means. Nonetheless, the siblings are
grateful to the alchemist.

Cagliostro pays another visit to Schnee's studio.
Yesterday was too hectic for Cagliostro to study the
paintings, but today the alchemist has time to truly
examine the multitude of artworks hanging around the
room. Something about the paintings grabs Cagliostro's
attention, drawing a rare instance of sentimental
introspection out of her.

Today, Schnee and Cagliostro are the only ones in
the studio. The sickly girl feels that her brother would
be better off if she weren't in his life. Cagliostro cuts
Schnee off and talks about her own tale of battling a
personal disease.

After hearing how Cagliostro had swapped bodies,
Schnee asks if she can do the same for her. Although
not impossible, the process is fraught with adverse
side effects, known and unknown. For starters, Schnee's
ability to paint may never be the same again. Schnee
listens in silence, staring at her hands the entire time.

Cagliostro returns from the Pillar of Vayoi with the
materials she needs for the body swap procedure.
Waiting for her at the studio is Himmel, who after
hearing about the plan from Schnee, refuses to let her
go through with it. Schnee pours out her frustrations,
lamenting that she doesn't want to be a burden on him.
Himmel emphatically denies that he ever felt that way.

Himmel and Schnee agree to forego the body swap
procedure—just as Cagliostro had predicted. The
alchemist hands the siblings new medicine she had
made in secret using the materials gathered from
Vayoi. Of course, she also demands a reward, to be
chosen at her discretion.

Lilith meant everything to Id. She raised him—told him
who to cut down. He truly believed it was all for the sake
of bringing salvation until it came out that she intended
to sacrifice Zegagrande in its entirety. Id pleaded with
her to the very end to change her mind. She refused, and
that sealed her fate.

Fifteen years ago, Id lost his home and family in
the Dahli disaster. He was found wandering alone
by Lilith, and she took the young boy in as her own.
Ever grateful to his adoptive mother, he poured his
heart and soul into being her sword. In time, he
became an Aviaeth general.

A fierce battle between Bahamut Versa, whom Lilith
had sealed inside Id, erupted in the sky. While battling
the powerful dragon, the crew helped Id regain his
senses. Together with , he banished
Bahamut to an alternate dimension, though this also
trapped the both of them. Rolan rescued them by
swapping places. To repay Rolan for his sacrifice and
atone for his sins, Id returns to Folca to take over as
Mr. Fix It in Rolan's absence.

Id and the crew are hard at work running errands
to improve Id's reputation when they receive a
request from Seedhollow. The city wants to relocate
families that lost their homes to Avia's assault and
would like a guard detail. Id thinks this job can help
him atone.

Id and the crew help escort displaced families to
Tempeal. One of the new settlers is a Harvin girl named
Shirolu who hates Id for what Avia did to her home.
Goblins suddenly attack the settlement, and Shirolu
gets lost in the chaos. Id hurries off to find her.

The day after the goblin attack, Shirolu visits Id to thank
him for saving her. He asks if there's anyway he can
make amends, to which the girl retorts that he can't
bring back the dead. The weight of his mistakes weighs
even heavier on him.

, Lyria, and Vyrn sense something is troubling
Id. He tells them Shirolu knows he was part of Avia. This
worries the crew, but Id is only focused on providing the
girl and the settlers with whatever they ask for.

Day by day, the settlers grow colder toward Id. It seems
his past involvement with Avia has come to light. The
crew attempt to rationalize the reasons behind his
misdeeds, but Id remains steadfast in bearing
responsibility.

Shirolu apologizes to Id for exposing his past to the
others. Id replies that he deserves the scorn of the
people he hurt. Suddenly the alarm bells ring: a supply
convoy is being attacked by goblins. Id and the crew
leave the village and save the convoy just in time, but
a second goblin force has invaded the settlement. Id
rushes back to fight the goblins alone. Shouts of
encouragement come from an unlikely ally: Shirolu.

The morning after the goblin attack, an open
discussion is held between Id and the settlers. Avia's
assault on their home of Seedhollow can never be
undone, but they also acknowledge that Id risked his
life to save them from goblins, thus earning their trust.
In light of the recent goblin attacks, concerns arise
over the safety of the settlement, but Shirolu quickly
pipes in that everything will work out because they
have Mr. Fix It.

On the remote island of Zinkenstill lived a young man and his best pal, Vyrn. 
As if guided by the invisible hand of fate, the young man crossed paths with
Lyria, kicking off his journey through the vast sky. Over the course of various
events, he assembled a diverse crew of allies from all over the Sky Realm,
becoming one of the youngest skyfaring captains to traverse the big blue.

On the remote island of Zinkenstill lived a young woman and her best pal, Vyrn. 
As if guided by the invisible hand of fate, the young woman crossed paths with
Lyria, kicking off her journey through the vast sky. Over the course of various
events, she assembled a diverse crew of allies from all over the Sky Realm,
becoming one of the youngest skyfaring captains to traverse the big blue.

Though Katalina was once a devoted knight of the Erste Empire, her duty now lies
solely with protecting Lyria, with whom she escaped the empire's grasp. As Lyria's
oldest friend, the two of them are as inseparable as family. Dependable for her
combat skills though she may be, she exhibits a surprisingly poor sense of direction
and leaves much to be desired in the culinary arts.

A seasoned helmsman who pilots the Grandcypher.
He knows his way around practically any airship and is renowned the skies over
for his skills at the wheel. Though blunt, Rackam is remarkably caring and enjoys
looking after others.

A young mage who idolizes sophistication. She's headstrong and tenacious—perhaps
even a little too much so at times.

Despite being haunted by his past, this old warrior still has a lot of fight
left in him. Though once a mercenary, Eugen now serves as a skyfarer—his experience
traveling the myriad skies proves a mighty boon to the crew. A crafty fellow, he often
mystifies others with proverbial tales accumulated from his years of wandering.

A mysterious woman who guides 's crew throughout their journey.
Rosetta is the incarnation of the primal beast Rose Queen and has traveled with
's father in the past.

A young woman who accidentally summoned Celeste, the primal beast of death, and
became a ghost. Though cursed by the primal beast to be forever bound to the misty 
island of her birth, she was released from that burden by  and the
crew. She loves her sister more than anything but was tragically separated from her.

A young knight who leads the Kingdom of Feendrache's Order of the
White Dragons. He travels the skies in search of knowledge that will
provide the foundation for his country's future.

The vice-captain of Feendrache's Order of the White Dragons. He is an ardent
champion of justice who despises evil. He possesses a happy-go-lucky attitude,
and his smile never wavers as he sets about his tasks.

This knight travels the skies in hopes of creating his ideal country. Having
studied the art of kingcraft from an early age, he is prone to being condescending.
He will, however, come up with any excuse to help a person in need and is actively
searching for vassals who share this philosophy.

With the blood of a dragon coursing through his veins, this knight brandishes a
mighty sword as a man would a stick. At one time he found himself victim of a court
conspiracy, causing him to flee his country and become a tragic hero. Despite
this, he is still loyal to the kingdom to this day and is admired by many.

A knight who serves as the captain of the Lumiel Order of Holy Knights. Although
she possesses a calm, steadfast personality, she suffers from an inferiority
complex over her height and seeks for ways to make herself taller.

A laid-back, jolly old fisherman who's content with passing his days atop his
mountain home. He was once a famed swordmaster with many pupils...
But that was a long time ago.

A swordswoman born to a long line of martial arts masters. She trains hard to
combine her family's martial arts and magic into her own style of swordplay. She
tends to coddle those younger than her, especially kids.

This legendary founder of the Eternal Rage Style believes in two things: his
fists. That's how he makes the impossible possible. Though he has come far in
his ascetic training, he continues his journey to one day knock out the god of
creation with a single punch.

A gallant warrior who hunts primal beasts for the Society. She often carries 
out duties with her partner Vaseraga. Though they may butt heads, they trust 
each other.

A Draph warrior who hunts primal beasts for the Society. He gives the impression 
of being a terrifying monster, but he's a calm soul who kindly extends a hand to 
the weak.

As a brilliant mage who introduced alchemy to the Sky Realm, none can rise to be
her equal. Utilizing alchemy, she regularly replaces her body with new vessels,
which she customizes to match her preferences. From her beginnings as a boy,
she's now in pursuit of her vision of absolute cuteness. Her true personality does
leap out from time to time, however.

A fierce swordsman chained to a fate most terrible, he was, at a great cost, able to
break and become Folca's local Mr. Fix It. He carries within his body a fearsome, 
destructive power derived from Bahamut, which he uses to overwhelm his enemies.
Forced to part with his beloved mother Lilith, it can be difficult deciphering his
thoughts.
